metadata.titleEn: Dataset of measured aboveground plant biomass and remote sensing net primary productivity in desert sites on theTibet Plateau (2000-2020)
metadata.description: A total of 52 sample sites were selected in the desert belts of Qinghai and Tibet for field sampling of aboveground biomass of vegetation during the vegetation growing season in 2019 and 2020. At the same time, the longitude, latitude and altitude of the experimental site were recorded using handheld GPS devices. The field setting method of the quadrate is as follows: select a section with uniform vegetation. When the vegetation is relatively abundant, the quadrate is set as a 10 m x10 m square plot, and when the vegetation is relatively sparse, the quadrate is set as a 30 m x30 m square plot or a 30 m x90 m rectangular plot. 3-5 small sample boxes (1m x 1m) were randomly thrown into the set sample plot to determine the specific location of the sample. Collect plant samples by sample harvesting method: register plant species, number of plants of each species and other information in sample area of 1 square meter. All kinds of plants in the quadrate were planted and mowed on the ground, and the collected herbaceous plant samples were placed in archives and marked with species, sample site name and number, collection time and other information. They were brought back to the laboratory and dried to a constant weight in a constant temperature drying oven at 65 ℃. The dry weight of the plant samples was measured. Finally, the aboveground biomass of the vegetation was calculated. In addition, two kinds of remote sensing net primary productivity (NPP) data of the 52 sample points were extracted by the longitude and latitude of the sampling points. (1) Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) from 2000 to 2018, and calculated the annual Integrated Enhanced Vegetation Index (IEVI). IEVI was highly correlated with net primary productivity (NPP). Can be used as a proxy indicator of net primary productivity (He et al. 2021, Science of The Total Environment). (2) Percentage of remote sensing net primary productivity (NPP) and its quality control (QC) in 2001-2020, NPP remote sensing data from MOD17A3HGF Version 6 product (https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/mod17a3hgfv006/), the net photosynthetic value (the total primary productivity - keep breathing) is calculated. In the sample sites with low vegetation coverage, there may be null value (NA) of remote sensing net primary productivity.
metadata.instructions: Document Name: The document is named "Desert Vegetation Productivity Dataset. XLSX", which represents measured aboveground plant biomass and remote sensing net primary productivity in 52 desert sites on theTibet Plateau Data reading method: The data set is stored in Excel file, and can be read, edited and copied directly by using Excel.

literatureList.titleEn: Lagged precipitation effect on plant productivity is influenced collectively by climate and edaphic factors in drylands

background: Global warming has intensified and accelerated the hydrologic cycle, causing precipitation patterns shifting to higher variability and more frequent dry and wet years, which is almost ubiquitous globally. Increasing precipitation variability may profoundly affect ecosystem functioning and structure, especially primary productivity. Therefore, understanding the relationship between plant productivity and precipitation is crucial to ecosystem function and also to humans who depend upon primary productivity for food, fiber and fuel. The lags in the response of ecosystems to changes in precipitation and "asymmetries" in the productivity-precipitation relationship modulate the effect of precipitation variability on productivity. The legacy effect of unusually dry or wet periods on biomass could last for less than one year up to seven years, of which one year is the most commonly reported lag time. Previous-year precipitation has been found to drive the current-year ecosystem process through lagged/legacy effect in multiple sites. At the interannual scale, the lagged precipitation effect is defined as the impact of previous-year precipitation conditions on the current structure and functioning of ecosystems. Drylands comprise 45% of the terrestrial earth surface, and precipitation is the most limiting factor to the functioning of dryland ecosystems. Drylands are inherently slow in the dynamics of soil nutrient buildup and plant productivity compared to other ecosystems, we would expect strong lagged effects of past climate conditions such as precipitation on current functioning. However, our ability to forecast ecosystem responses to climate change is still hindered by our understanding of the mechanisms underlying the lagged precipitation effect.
research objective: In these perspectives, we hypothesize that compared with the unlagged ecosystems, the lagged ones are characterized by (i) lower sensitivity of productivity response to precipitation, (ii) higher interannual precipitation variability and more occurrences of dry and wet years, and (iii) higher sensitivity of other environmental factors to precipitation. To test our hypotheses, we divide terrestrial ecosystems of the Northern Hemisphere drylands into the lagged and unlagged types.
challenges: However, it is still unclear how other environmental factors affect the lagged response of ecosystems to changes in precipitation. Most studies focused on the biotic mechanisms; however, it remains largely uncertain how climatic and edaphic factors may interact with lagged precipitation effects. However, our ability to forecast ecosystem responses to climate change is still hindered by our understanding of the mechanisms underlying the lagged precipitation effect. However, we do not know whether the lagged precipitation effect is associated with precipitation variability.
methods: We used the enhanced vegetation index (EVI) to estimate primary productivity. The MOD13C2 version 6 EVI dataset at 0.05° spatial resolution and monthly compositing periods for the period from February 2000 to December 2018 was employed. For each pixel in the Northern Hemisphere drylands, linear regression and multiple linear models between current-year iEVI and current-year precipitation and/or previous-year precipitation were fitted. To test the first hypothesis, i.e., the lagged type had a lower sensitivity of productivity response to precipitation. We fitted the regressions between iEVI and precipitation for each pixel. To test the second hypothesis, i.e., the lagged type had higher interannual precipitation variability and more occurrences of dry and wet years. We calculated the coefficient of variation (CV) of annual precipitation and the occurrences of dry and wet years for each pixel based on 19-year annual precipitation data. To test the third hypothesis, i.e., the lagged type had a higher sensitivity of other environmental factors to precipitation. We compared the difference between the two types in terms of climatic-edaphic factors, to explore what factors were responsible for the lagged precipitation effect.
dataset: The Tropical Rainfall Measuring Mission (TRMM) product (TRMM 3B42) at 0.25° spatial and daily temporal resolution for the period of 1999-2018 were used. We used the enhanced vegetation index (EVI) to estimate primary productivity. The MOD13C2 version 6 EVI dataset at 0.05° spatial resolution and monthly compositing periods for the period from February 2000 to December 2018 was employed.
findings: Our results show that productivity is less sensitive to precipitation in lagged type than unlagged type along the MAP gradients. Our results support this viewpoint that the lagged precipitation effect plays a vital role in modifying the productivity-precipitation relationship.

Verification.Question: Is it possible to rely on the enhanced vegetation index (EVI) as a proxy for net primary productivity (NPP) in dryland ecosystems?
Does the collection of remote sensing NPP data involve quality control measures?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the primary method for estimating aboveground biomass in dryland ecosystems based on remote sensing data, field sampling, or a combination of both?
Are the challenges in understanding the lagged precipitation effect more related to biotic mechanisms, climatic factors, or edaphic interactions?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the data collection methods used for measuring plant aboveground biomass in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau desert zones?
What datasets are used to estimate net primary productivity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau region?
Concept Completion.Answer: enhanced vegetation index dataset, remotely sensed net primary productivity dataset

Concept Completion.Question: Where were the sampling points located for collecting data on plant aboveground biomass in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?

Example.Question: What is an example of a method used to estimate net primary productivity from remote sensing data in arid regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a method used to estimate net primary productivity from remote sensing data in arid regions is the use of the enhanced vegetation index (EVI), which is calculated from satellite data. The annual integrated EVI (iEVI) is derived and correlates highly with net primary productivity, serving as a proxy indicator.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of challenges faced when using remote sensing data to study primary productivity in desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: One challenge when using remote sensing data to study primary productivity in desert ecosystems is dealing with potential missing data (NA values) in remote sensing net primary productivity datasets, especially for areas with low vegetation cover.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods for estimating plant aboveground biomass in desert regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: 10m x 10m plots, 30m x 30m plots, 30m x 90m plots, 1m x 1m subplots, plant species and counts recorded, plant samples dried and weighed

Feature Specification.Question: What specific attributes are used to derive net primary productivity (NPP) from remote sensing data?
Feature Specification.Answer: enhanced vegetation index (EVI), annual integrated form (iEVI), net photosynthesis, total primary productivity, plant maintenance respiration, quality control percentages

Feature Specification.Question: What challenges might arise in the data collection process for establishing the relationship between plant productivity and precipitation in dryland ecosystems?
Feature Specification.Answer: lagged response of ecosystems to precipitation changes, interaction of climatic and edaphic factors, variability in precipitation patterns, legacy effects of unusual dry or wet periods, slow dynamics of soil nutrient buildup and plant productivity

Quantification.Question: How many sample sites were investigated for above-ground biomass measurements and remote sensing net primary productivity data collection?
Over what period were the enhanced vegetation index (EVI) and remote sensing net primary productivity (NPP) data collected?
What is the size range of the sampling plots used for vegetation biomass collection?
Quantification.Answer: 10 meters x 10 meters to 30 meters x 90 meters

Definition.Question: What is the 'enhanced vegetation index (EVI)' and how is it used in estimating primary productivity?
Definition.Answer: The enhanced vegetation index (EVI) is a satellite-derived index that is used to estimate primary productivity by measuring vegetation greenness. In the context of the dataset, EVI data was employed to calculate the annual integrated enhanced vegetation index (iEVI), which correlates highly with net primary productivity (NPP) and can serve as a substitute indicator for NPP.

Definition.Question: What does 'remote sensing net primary productivity (NPP)' entail, and how is it calculated?
Definition.Answer: Remote sensing net primary productivity (NPP) involves estimating the amount of biomass produced by vegetation using satellite data. It is calculated from the net photosynthetic value, which is the total primary productivity minus the maintenance respiration of plants. In the dataset, NPP data was extracted from the MOD17A3HGF Version 6 product, covering the years 2001-2020.

Definition.Question: What does 'lagged precipitation effect' mean in relation to ecosystem productivity?
Definition.Answer: The 'lagged precipitation effect' refers to the impact that precipitation conditions from a previous year have on the current year's ecosystem structure and functioning. This concept is particularly relevant in dryland ecosystems, where precipitation is a limiting factor, and indicates that past climate conditions can strongly influence current productivity responses and ecosystem dynamics.

Comparison.Question: How do field-based data collection methods for measuring plant aboveground biomass in desert ecosystems compare to remote sensing techniques like the enhanced vegetation index (EVI) for estimating primary productivity?
Comparison.Answer: Field-based methods involve physical sampling of vegetation during the peak growth period using sample plots, where plant species and biomass are measured directly. In contrast, remote sensing techniques like the enhanced vegetation index (EVI) estimate primary productivity using satellite data, providing a broader spatial coverage and capturing data over time. Both methods aim to quantify primary productivity but differ in scope and data acquisition techniques.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection challenges between measuring net primary productivity (NPP) using field sampling in desert ecosystems and utilizing MODIS remote sensing products?
Comparison.Answer: Field sampling in desert ecosystems can be challenging due to the need for precise measurements and physical accessibility to remote locations, potentially limiting data collection to specific periods. Remote sensing using MODIS products, such as the MOD17A3HGF Version 6, provides continuous and large-scale data but may face challenges like cloud cover, resolution limitations, and data accuracy in areas with low vegetation cover, which could result in data gaps or NA values.

Interpretation.Question: How might the choice of spatial resolution and compositing periods in vegetation indices affect the interpretation of primary productivity in dryland ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial resolution and compositing periods can influence the sensitivity and accuracy of primary productivity estimates. A finer spatial resolution may capture more detailed variations in vegetation cover, while the choice of compositing periods can affect the temporal dynamics captured by the index. The use of enhanced vegetation index (EVI) at 0.05° spatial resolution and monthly compositing periods can help in examining interannual variability and the lagged effects of precipitation on productivity, as seen in the interpretation of ecosystems' responses to precipitation variability.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges could arise in using remote sensing data to estimate net primary productivity in regions with low vegetation cover?
Interpretation.Answer: Remote sensing data, such as the MOD17A3HGF Version 6 product for net primary productivity (NPP), may encounter challenges in regions with low vegetation cover due to potential data gaps or NA values. This can complicate efforts to accurately assess productivity and necessitates robust quality control and data validation techniques to ensure reliable estimates. The presence of empty values in areas with low vegetation cover highlights the need for careful interpretation and possibly supplementary data collection methods to fill in these gaps.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the variability in vegetation productivity measurements when using remote sensing techniques in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variability in vegetation productivity measurements using remote sensing techniques in arid regions can be attributed to the low vegetation cover, which may result in null values in remote sensing net primary productivity data. Additionally, the enhanced vegetation index (EVI) and its integration (iEVI) are used as proxy indicators, and their correlation with net primary productivity may vary based on environmental conditions and data quality control percentages.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes might contribute to the challenges in predicting ecosystem responses to precipitation variability in dryland areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in predicting ecosystem responses to precipitation variability in dryland areas may be caused by the complex interplay of climatic, biotic, and edaphic factors, as well as the lagged effects of previous-year precipitation on current ecosystem structure and function. The legacy effects of past droughts or wet periods, which can last from less than one year to up to seven years, further complicate the prediction of ecosystem responses.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of varying the spatial resolution of data collection on the accuracy and reliability of estimating net primary productivity in dryland ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Varying the spatial resolution of data collection could affect the accuracy and reliability of estimating net primary productivity in dryland ecosystems by influencing the sensitivity of productivity response to precipitation, as demonstrated by the use of enhanced vegetation index (EVI) datasets at different spatial resolutions. A higher resolution may capture more detailed spatial variability in vegetation, whereas lower resolution might miss finer-scale heterogeneities.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the choice of vegetation index, such as the enhanced vegetation index (EVI), influence the interpretation of productivity-precipitation relationships in ecosystems with lagged responses?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The choice of vegetation index, such as the enhanced vegetation index (EVI), can significantly influence the interpretation of productivity-precipitation relationships. EVI's ability to estimate primary productivity, particularly in ecosystems with lagged responses, allows for discerning lower sensitivity of productivity to precipitation and identifying interannual precipitation variability and occurrences of dry and wet years, which are critical in understanding lagged ecosystem responses.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the implications of including or excluding previous-year precipitation data when modeling ecosystem productivity using datasets like those from the Tropical Rainfall Measuring Mission (TRMM)?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Including previous-year precipitation data when modeling ecosystem productivity could highlight the lagged effects of past climate conditions on current ecosystem functioning, particularly in dryland ecosystems where such effects are pronounced. This approach could reveal lower sensitivity of productivity to current precipitation and provide insights into the legacy effects of precipitation variability, enhancing the understanding of ecosystem responses over time.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to consider the lagged effects of precipitation on plant productivity when analyzing ecosystem responses in dryland areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Considering the lagged effects of precipitation is important because it helps in understanding how past climatic conditions, such as previous-year precipitation, influence current ecosystem structure and functioning, particularly in drylands where precipitation is a limiting factor.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivates the use of the enhanced vegetation index (EVI) as a proxy for estimating primary productivity in ecological studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The use of EVI is motivated by its ability to provide a reliable proxy for primary productivity, due to its high correlation with net primary productivity, allowing researchers to estimate productivity at a large scale using remote sensing data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the process of field sampling conducted to measure aboveground biomass in desert regions of Qinghai and Tibet, and what equipment is used during this process?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Field sampling to measure aboveground biomass involves selecting a uniformly vegetated area and setting up plots of varying sizes depending on vegetation density. For denser vegetation, a 10m x 10m square plot is used, and for sparser vegetation, larger plots like 30m x 30m or 30m x 90m are used. Within these plots, smaller 1m x 1m quadrats are randomly placed for sampling. Plant samples are collected by cutting them at ground level, recording species and plant count, and drying them in a laboratory at 65°C to determine dry weight. A handheld GPS device is used to record the location, including latitude, longitude, and altitude.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approach is taken to integrate remote sensing data with field measurements for estimating net primary productivity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The methodological approach involves extracting remote sensing data, specifically the Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) and remote sensing net primary productivity (NPP), using the latitude and longitude of 52 sample points. The EVI data from 2000-2018 is used to calculate the integrated EVI (iEVI), which is highly correlated with NPP and can serve as a surrogate for NPP. Additionally, remote sensing NPP data from the MOD17A3HGF Version 6 product is used, which accounts for net photosynthesis, calculated as gross primary productivity minus plant maintenance respiration.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed to handle missing values in remote sensing net primary productivity data for areas with low vegetation coverage in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In areas with low vegetation coverage, there may be missing values (NA) in the remote sensing net primary productivity (NPP) data. While the specific procedures for handling these missing values are not detailed, common practices could include using interpolation methods, removing data points with missing values, or using statistical models to estimate missing values based on available data. These methods help ensure accurate analysis and integration with other data sources.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of remote sensing data enhance the estimation of net primary productivity in desert regions?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of remote sensing data, such as the enhanced vegetation index (EVI) and remote sensing net primary productivity (NPP) data from products like MOD17A3HGF, enhances the estimation of net primary productivity by providing spatially comprehensive and temporally consistent measurements that correlate highly with NPP. This approach allows for the extraction of productivity data across large and remote desert regions using satellite-derived indices.

Enablement.Question: What are the challenges associated with using remote sensing data for estimating productivity in low-vegetation areas?
Enablement.Answer: The challenges of using remote sensing data for estimating productivity in low-vegetation areas include the potential presence of null values in remote sensing NPP data due to low vegetation coverage. This can affect the accuracy and completeness of productivity estimates, necessitating careful quality control and data processing to account for gaps or inconsistencies.

Expectation.Question: Why might the enhanced vegetation index (EVI) and net primary productivity (NPP) show discrepancies in areas with low vegetation cover?
Expectation.Answer: In areas with low vegetation cover, remote sensing data for net primary productivity might contain null values. This could cause discrepancies between EVI, which is used as a proxy for NPP, and actual NPP measurements.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be a need to use a larger or varied plot size during field sampling of vegetation biomass in desert regions?
Expectation.Answer: When vegetation is relatively sparse, larger plot sizes such as 30 meters by 30 meters or 30 meters by 90 meters are used to account for the distribution and variability of plant species, ensuring accurate sampling of vegetation biomass.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using enhanced vegetation index (EVI) as a proxy for estimating plant productivity in the context of data collection on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The enhanced vegetation index (EVI) is considered a reliable proxy for estimating plant productivity due to its high correlation with net primary productivity (NPP), as indicated by the calculation of integrated EVI (iEVI). This method is effective in capturing variability in plant productivity across different sample sites, especially when assessing large-scale remote sensing data such as those from the MOD13C2 and MOD17A3HGF products. However, its effectiveness may be limited in areas with low vegetation cover where remote sensing NPP might have missing values.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential challenges in collecting field data on aboveground biomass in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, and how might these challenges impact the data's accuracy and reliability?
Judgmental.Answer: Collecting field data on aboveground biomass in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau presents challenges such as the variability in vegetation cover, the harsh and remote environment, and the logistical complexities of conducting fieldwork in such areas. These factors can impact the accuracy and reliability of the data, potentially leading to underestimation or overestimation of biomass. The need to adjust plot sizes based on vegetation density and ensuring consistent sampling methods are crucial to mitigating these challenges.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the possibility of integrating additional remote sensing datasets to improve the understanding of primary productivity in dryland ecosystems of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating additional remote sensing datasets could significantly enhance the understanding of primary productivity in dryland ecosystems. By incorporating datasets that provide varied spatial and temporal resolutions, such as those from the TRMM for precipitation or other spectral indices, researchers can gain more comprehensive insights into the interactions between climatic factors and ecosystem productivity. This approach may help to overcome limitations associated with current datasets and offer a more nuanced understanding of productivity-precipitation relationships and lagged effects in these ecosystems.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods account for variations in vegetation density during biomass sampling.
Assertion.Answer: Data collection methods involve setting up plots with different sizes depending on vegetation density. For dense vegetation, a 10m x 10m plot is used, while for sparse vegetation, larger plots like 30m x 30m or 30m x 90m are set up. Within these plots, smaller 1m x 1m subplots are used for detailed sampling.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure how the enhanced vegetation index (EVI) is used to assess primary productivity over time.
Assertion.Answer: The enhanced vegetation index (EVI) is used to estimate primary productivity by calculating an integrated index (iEVI) over time, which correlates highly with net primary productivity (NPP). EVI data from 2000-2018 is utilized to analyze productivity trends.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how remote sensing data can have missing values for net primary productivity in some sampling points.
Assertion.Answer: Remote sensing data for net primary productivity (NPP) may have missing values in areas with low vegetation cover, as these conditions can lead to gaps in data quality or coverage when using satellite-derived measurements like those from the MOD17A3HGF product.
